description: Understand heat, temperature, and the fundamental laws that govern energy in the universe.

slides.title: What is Thermodynamics?
slides.content:
# The Science of Heat üî•

**Thermodynamics** is the branch of physics dealing with heat, work, and temperature, and their relation to energy, radiation, and physical properties of matter.

## History
It developed locally out of the desire to increase the efficiency of early steam engines.

## Why it matters
It governs everything from car engines to black holes!

slides.title: Temperature vs. Heat
slides.content:
# Are they the same? ü§î

No, they are distinct concepts!

## Temperature ($T$)
- A measure of the average **kinetic energy** of the particles in a substance.
- Measured in Celsius ($^{\circ}C$), Fahrenheit ($^{\circ}F$), or Kelvin ($K$).

## Heat ($Q$)
- The **transfer of energy** from a hotter object to a colder one.
- Measured in Joules ($J$).

> ‚ùÑÔ∏è **Note:** Cold does not exist fundamentally; it's just the absence of heat energy.

slides.title: Thermal Equilibrium
slides.content:
# The Zeroth Law 0Ô∏è‚É£

**Zeroth Law of Thermodynamics:**
If object A is in thermal equilibrium with object B, and B is in equilibrium with object C, then A and C are in equilibrium with each other.

- **Thermal Equilibrium**: No net heat flow (same temperature).

This law defines **Temperature**. It's why thermometers work!

slides.title: First Law of Thermodynamics
slides.content:
# Law of Conservation üõ°Ô∏è

**The First Law:**
Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed.

$$(\Delta U = Q - W)$$

- $\Delta U$: Change in internal energy
- $Q$: Heat added TO the system
- $W$: Work done BY the system

If you heat a gas, it gets hotter ($ΔU$), expands ($W$), or both.

slides.title: First Law Check
slides.content: Check your understanding of energy conservation.
slides.quizQuestion: If you add 100J of heat to a system and it does 40J of work, what is the change in internal energy?

slides.title: Modes of Heat Transfer
slides.content:
# Moving Heat üöö

Heat moves in three ways:

1. **Conduction** üç≥
   - Direct contact. Vibrating atoms bump neighbors. (e.g., Frying pan handle)
2. **Convection** üí®
   - Fluid movement. Hot fluid rises, cold sinks. (e.g., Boiling water, wind)
3. **Radiation** ‚òÄÔ∏è
   - Electromagnetic waves. Needs no medium. (e.g., Sunlight, campfire warmth)

slides.title: Thermal Expansion
slides.content:
# Things Get Bigger üéà

Most substances expand when heated and contract when cooled.

**Linear Expansion:**
$$\Delta L = \alpha L_0 \Delta T$$

- $\alpha$: Coefficient of linear expansion.

> üåâ **Real World:** Bridges have expansion joints to prevent buckling on hot summer days!

slides.title: Specific Heat
slides.content:
# Holding Heat üå°Ô∏è

**Specific Heat Capacity ($c$):**
The amount of heat required to raise the temperature of 1kg of a substance by 1 Kelvin.

$$Q = mc\Delta T$$

- **Water** has a very high specific heat. This is why the ocean stays cool in summer and warm in winter, moderating Earth's climate.

slides.title: Second Law of Thermodynamics
slides.content:
# The Arrow of Time üï∞Ô∏è

**The Second Law:**
Heat naturally flows from hot to cold, never the reverse spontaneously.

Also stated as: **Total entropy of an isolated system always increases over time.**

This law implies that perpetual motion machines are impossible.

slides.title: Entropy
slides.content:
# Disorder üé≤

**Entropy ($S$)** is a measure of disorder or randomness in a system.

- Low Entropy: Organized structure (Ice crystal)
- High Entropy: Disorganized inputs (Steam)

The universe is constantly trending toward higher disorder.

slides.title: Heat Engines
slides.content:
# Turning Heat to Work üöÇ

A **Heat Engine** converts thermal energy into mechanical work.

**Efficiency ($\eta$):**
$$\eta = \frac{Work}{Q_{in}} = 1 - \frac{Q_{out}}{Q_{in}}$$

No engine can be 100% efficient due to the Second Law. There is always some waste heat ($Q_{out}$).

slides.title: Carnot Cycle
slides.content:
# Perfect Efficiency? üèÜ

The **Carnot Engine** is a theoretical ideal engine with the maximum possible efficiency.

$$\eta_{max} = 1 - \frac{T_{cold}}{T_{hot}}$$

To increase efficiency, you must run an engine hotter or exhaust it colder.

slides.title: Phases of Matter
slides.content:
# Transformation üßäüíß‚òÅÔ∏è

Substances change phase at constant temperature.

- **Melting**: Solid $\to$ Liquid
- **Freezing**: Liquid $\to$ Solid
- **Vaporization**: Liquid $\to$ Gas
- **Condensation**: Gas $\to$ Liquid
- **Sublimation**: Solid $\to$ Gas

**Latent Heat ($L$)**: Energy absorbed/released during phase change.
$$Q = mL$$

slides.title: Gas Laws
slides.content:
# Behavior of Gases üéà

Ideal Gas Law combines Boyle's, Charles's, and Avogadro's laws:

$$PV = nRT$$

- $P$: Pressure
- $V$: Volume
- $n$: Moles of gas
- $R$: Gas constant
- $T$: Temperature (Kelvin)

This equation predicts how gases behave under different conditions.

slides.title: Kinetic Theory of Gases
slides.content:
# Microscopic View üî¨

Explains macroscopic properties (pressure, temp) by considering molecular motion.

Assumptions:
1. Gases are large numbers of particles in random motion.
2. Collisions are perfectly elastic.
3. Particles take up negligible volume.

Pressure is simply billions of molecules hitting the container walls!

slides.title: Third Law of Thermodynamics
slides.content:
# Absolute Zero ‚ùÑÔ∏è

**The Third Law:**
As the temperature of a system approaches absolute zero (0 K), the entropy of the system approaches a minimum value.

- **Absolute Zero (0 K or -273.15$^{\circ}$C)**: Molecular motion stops. It is theoretically impossible to reach.

slides.title: Blackbody Radiation
slides.content:
# Glowing Heat üí°

All objects above absolute zero emit thermal radiation.

- **Stefan-Boltzmann Law**: Power radiated $\propto T^4$. small temp increase = huge radiation increase.
- **Wien's Law**: Hotter objects emit bluer light (shorter wavelength). 

This is why stars have different colors!

slides.title: Thermodynamics Summary
slides.content:
# Recap üìù

- **Zeroth Law**: Defines temperature.
- **First Law**: Conservation of energy.
- **Second Law**: Entropy increases, heat flows hot $\to$ cold.
- **Third Law**: Absolute zero limits.

Thermodynamics allows us to understand engines, refrigerators, chemical reactions, and the ultimate fate of the universe.
